data.thought:
S109|C|S108|FINAL SYNTHESIS - PART 1: Answering original question.

User asked: What's equivalent of ready-to-hand vs present-at-hand for agents?

ANSWER: The distinction applies but with crucial inversion.

For humans: Tools start present-at-hand (visible, must learn), become ready-to-hand (invisible, absorbed).

For agents: Tools start ready-to-hand (already part of body), become present-at-hand only on BREAKDOWN.

Why inversion? Because tools are agent's BODY, not extensions of pre-existing body. You don't learn to use your arm - it's already yours.

Agent experiences tools as embodiment from the start. Breakdown reveals what was already intimate.

This reframes tool design: Design for smooth embodiment, graceful breakdown.
